div.p: Greetings. I (reverend father in Christ), truly have nothing to write.
I sent to the legate, but he himself has nothing either. Nothing is brought to us from Italy; everything is silent now.

What this portends, I do not know; perhaps they are nurturing some monster, which is soon to erupt. Regarding the crowned one, since you absolutely wish it, I will comply; however, I will give more abundant thanks when my wife has received it, although I reluctantly accept from him to whom I owe. A rumor was spread here the day before about the death of the Duke of Savoy; but I can affirm nothing.
What is happening in Germany is unknown to us.

If I live, I will come to you after Easter, and then about all matters. You will then give me a few hours, which you will steal for yourself; for I will not be torn away from you so suddenly as happened last year, since you are not the least reason for my coming to you, unless (which I certainly fear) I am going to be mute in your presence, although when absent I never lack something I wish you to know. I have received everything from Mr. Gesner; I will write, if I have time, after eight days. There is no need to be concerned about the cost of transportation, as everything has been abundantly paid.

Farewell, reverend father in Christ, and forgive me for bothering you with empty letters; for although I had nothing to write, I still wanted to write, so that you too would know that I have nothing. All of ours wish you well.
Give our greetings to all of yours.
Johannes Fabricius, your most observant. We fear nothing about Beccaria.
To the most illustrious man, excellent in learning and piety, Mr. Heinrich Bullinger, the most vigilant Antistes of the Church of ZÃ¼rich, his lord and patron to be observed in many respects.
